reasoning:
First off, NFLX falls outside my Circle of Competence. I’m comfortable with businesses I can relate to—consumer staples, banks, insurance, utilities—where I understand the economics and the competitive landscape. Streaming video is complex, with shifting content rights, evolving technology, intense competition, and uncertain subscriber economics. I simply don’t know it well enough to bet the farm.

On the moat front, streaming services face low switching costs and razor-thin moats. A viewer can cancel Netflix and hop over to Disney+, Amazon or Apple TV+. Unlike Coca-Cola’s brand or See’s Candies’ local pricing power, Netflix’s advantage is fleeting.

Management may be talented—Reed Hastings has built a global subscriber base—but they’re in a content arms race, burning cash to acquire or produce shows. That’s not the type of conservative capital allocation I admire at companies like GEICO or BNSF.

Financially, Netflix has loaded up on debt to fund content, and with zero data provided here, I’m flying blind on cash flow consistency or leverage. High fixed costs and subscriber churn leave its earnings anything but consistent.

Without any reliable valuation or intrinsic value estimate, there’s no margin of safety. I’d be guessing at whether today’s price is 10% or 100% over intrinsic value—a recipe for permanent loss.

Long-term, the streaming field will be cutthroat, and Netflix must keep outspending competitors just to tread water. Compared to opportunities in my portfolio—from Coca-Cola’s enduring brand to Apple’s sticky ecosystem—Netflix doesn’t match up.

When in doubt, I say no. I’d rather hold wonderful businesses at fair prices than fair businesses at wonderful prices. NFLX is a fair business in a highly competitive field I don’t fully grasp, with no margin of safety. I’ll pass.

moat_analysis.details: Insufficient data for comprehensive moat analysis
